so when you are thinking about selecting storage to use for your applications
there's three main things that you want to think about one is what type of
storage makes the most sense for your application they have different characteristics different semantics
different interfaces different permissions models you also have different features and performance
characteristics and lastly you want to consider the economics of what you're
considering so let's talk about each of these generally there are three types of
storage there's file block and object file
storage is data that's stored in files in a directory hierarchy with particular
metadata associated with each file in other words it's your data stored
natively in a file system when we talk about file in an enterprise context it's
data that can be accessed over the network by multiple at the same time so you can think of it
as network-attached storage in block
storage it's a disk or a set of disks in which data is stored directly as chunks
called blocks and these disks core set of disks are typically connected to a
single host you can think of it as locally attached storage and lastly with
object storage data is stored in a container called an object that is
identified by a unique key and it's stored in a flat space so not a
hierarchical directory and there is a simple API to both get and put data over
typically over the internet so why is
file storage so popular first it works natively with operating systems so
operating systems are designed around file storage it's the abstraction layer
by which operating systems represent their files it also provides shared
access while providing consistency guarantees and locking functionality so
again shared storage requires multiple clients to be able to access that data
so things like ability to lock out other users from accessing that same file are
critical and lastly the hierarchical namespace it's just a simple logical and
helpful way to organize your data so
let's compare these in terms of relatively compare these in terms of performance block is generally the
lowest latency but doesn't scale to the
multiple gigabytes of throughput of both file and object so it's ideal for
applications like databases that are typically running on a single instance or computer and provide and require
is the lowest latency file is designed for low consistent latency but also can
provide multiple gigabytes per second of throughput an object provides the
highest levels of throughput but it's not really designed for the low latency sensitive applications so you're all
here because you're interested in seeing how file file storage can apply to your
workloads and we launched EFS about a year and a half ago and before EFS was
available well you had to do if you wanted shared file storage on AWS is do
yourself so this is typically what we found customers were doing you would
need to set up an ec2 instance with one or more EBS volumes depending on your capacity and for high availability you
would need to duplicate that environment in another availability zone and then you would need to copy the data over
into the other availability zone for that redundancy so you'd had multiple
ec2 instances multiple EBS volumes and then you would have to manage the filesystem layer and data copy but now
we have elastic file system which is our native fully managed file service when
we designed EFS we designed it with three core tenants wanted it to be
simple elastic and scalable and built upon high availability and durability so
simple it's fully managed again if you think back to that diagram just a moment
ago all of that complexity the hardware the networking the file layer is all
abstracted in a fully managed service you can create a file system in seconds
literally just a couple of clicks in the console even the pricing is simple and we'll get
to that in a little bit when we get covered the economics in terms of
elasticity file systems grow and shrink automatically as you add or move files
you know there's no need to provision at any time either for a performance or
capacity and you only pay for the storage that you use and in terms of
scalability file systems can grow to petabytes scale and the throughput
scales according to the amount of capacity automatically and regardless of
how large your file systems get we still provide the low consistent latency and a
file system can scale out to be accessed by tens hundreds even thousands of NFS
clients concurrently it's built upon
high availability and durability every file system object in amazon EFS is
mirrored across multiple availability zones so it's designed to sustain any
single availability zone offline which is far superior than traditional Nazz or
network attached storage models so we feel it's appropriate for all production in tier zero level applications EFS is
also designed to meet a wide range of different workloads from highly scale
out analytics style and media workflows all the way to low latency metadata
intensive jobs like development tooling and container storage EFS is able to
